instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: Replace keyboard is same story as <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>? Same job and same screw I can put?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: No, it is similar to <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and it is complete HELL. Do not think you can pull the key caps and swap them over on the new keyboard as damage to the butterfly mechanism is guaranteed. Expect to just buy a complete topcase with the correct keyboard layout and avoid all the drama!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: When you say to damage the butterfly mechanism you mean if I replace only the keys? I want to replace the full keyboard and pull it out removing rivets and put screws instead.Why butterfly mechanism damage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: Because "local" keyboard layouts are usually hard to get. So if you are thinking of swapping over keys to correct a UK keyboard to lets say Spanish you will fuck it up.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message:
Ok, now I understand what you mean. Yes in <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is preaty easy. Will tell customers only UK is possible.
And what about just keyboard replacment? Same job as <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>? Remove rivets and put same screws?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: I replaced already 10 keyboards only, not too difficult but make sure to charge double the price compared to the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> just because as Duke says, it kinda sucks! And make sure to use the rightkey board as after installation you do not want to have to remove it again.....

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> replace keyboard
threads.message: also, putting the screws in sucks big time.....i usually put screws in at a slight angle. otherwise they tend to pop out.
